conversation.content: [measured] Well, I know this is, um, awkward after three years of not speaking, but I'm here because, [clinical], your pacemaker manufacturer is facing, [careful], serious liability issues and, uh, you could be entitled to significant compensation.

[bitter] So you finally show up when there's, [hollow], money involved, not when I had the surgery, not when I nearly, [trembling], died from the complications, but now when you can, [cold], build a case.
Um, Dad, I mean—

[exhausted] Don't call me that like you, uh, suddenly remember who I am when for years you've treated me like, [sinking], just another name in your contact list that you, well, never quite get around to calling, like I'm some, [distant], unfinished task.
[professional] The device in your chest has a forty-three percent failure rate that the company, [steady], knew about but chose to hide from patients and doctors.
[weary] I suppose you need me to, um, sign something, give a deposition about how this thing, [gesturing], has been ticking inside me like a bomb for, well, five years now.

[conflicted] Look, I, um, I understand you're angry but this isn't just about, [struggling], the money—these people knowingly put thousands of lives at risk including, well, yours, and someone needs to, [firm], hold them accountable.

You always were good at, um, making everything sound noble when really you're just, [accusatory], doing your job, collecting your thirty percent while the rest of us, well, live with the, [heavy], consequences.
[defensive] I'm trying to, um, help you here and, well, maybe fix something between us while, [quieter], there's still time.
[scoffs] Um, still time.
Well, yeah, I mean—
[resigned] The doctors say this device could, um, fail any day now and when it does, I have maybe, [shaking], ten minutes to get to a hospital before my heart, well, just stops. [long pause]
[stunned] Jesus, I didn't, um, I mean, the case files didn't mention that the failure was, [voice breaking], that catastrophic or that, well, imminent.
[flat] Well, now you know why I stopped, um, making plans beyond next week and why your mother's spare bedroom became, [heavy], my permanent address after I couldn't, like, live alone anymore.
[guilty] Mom never, um, told me.
She said you had enough on your plate with your, [sardonic], important cases saving the world one lawsuit at a time.

[soft] I could, um, get you moved up on the surgery list, I mean, I know the head of cardiology at Presbyterian and he owes me, [determined], several favors from the stent litigation we won last year.

[tired] After seventy-four years, my body's too weak for another surgery and honestly, well, I'm tired of being cut open, tired of, [fading], fighting, tired of waiting for my son to remember I exist beyond being a potential, um, plaintiff.
[breaking] Dad, I'm sorry, I mean, I know I can't just show up here and fix everything with, well, legal documents and, um, settlement offers.
[quietly] Just sit with me for a while, no papers, no, [gentle], depositions, just sit.
